Articles.Content: Since ksp can be ran on a mac is it or will it be possible to run on a ipad?
No. iPad doesn't have anywhere near the strength needed to run KSP.
Nor does it have the required controls.
And IOS is much different that OSX.

Not to mention all of the hullabaloo you have to go through to get an app workable and approved on the app store. Although it'd be very cool to see, even if it was only the VAB or something rudimentary. Long story short, it's not going to happen in the forseeable future.
The future is here with the iPad Air 2 you could possibly run KSP. But you would need to use the metal API with Unity 5.

It would be very cool, however, if you could run a (simplified) VAB and SPH environment on a IOS or Droid tablet. Design crafts on the go! Export the .craft to your KSP install! fly it in all its flawed glory!

it would only take as much development time as a full (scratch-to-finish) release to pull that off! yay!

I have 2h30mins of battery when playing ksp on my new MacBook Pro. So, the ipad would need to be plugged in.

I believe the viable approach would be a streaming app that runs the game on a desktop and streams it to a pad over the net. Although the controls could be a problem, even for VAB - I often find myself struggling with fingers on 3 keys at once, while manipulating the mouse...

Well, as KSP stores all its data in textfiles it is technically possible to write apps like a craft-creator. With integrated KER one can set up some test crafts, checking stats like delta-v or TWR on the go.

Maybe a export system can generte the .craft files for using with stock KSP.

The editor does not need to look like KSP's, it can be very simple.

Hm, the longer I think of it, looks like a cool project. I wanted to do some Android stuff for a long time.

However, it would take a lot time to get a working lpha-version, and time to spare is something I don't have much :-(

There's no way KSP can run on the iPad. If you really want to play on a tablet and if you can afford it you can probably run it just fine on the MS Surface Pro 3...

Stock would be fine (to begin with... )

Keep in mind that many of the limitations of the editor are not enforced in the craft files. Additionally, they contain floating point values, which might end up slightly different on processors with different architectures. I am no expert but I suspect tablets do not use X86 based processors?

If more than one program for creating these files would exist, much care would need to be taken to keep the files compatible and consistent. If you cannot trust that the craft files from the tablet app work and are the same when transferred to PC, what is the appeal?

Sounds like asking for trouble for not much benefit tbh...

If you cannot trust that the craft files from the tablet app work and are the same when transferred to PC, what is the appeal?

Moar fireworks! And "a lot of trouble for not much benefit" is pretty much how I run my space program... Efficiency is over-rated. Ask any civil servant

I cannot possibly comment on the technical feasability of such an undertaking, however.

As far as I know mobile processors use the ARM instruction set which is in fact, different, from x86/x64. But considering the fact that it's so """easy""" to port unity applications to android/iOS I don't know how hard it could be to port the VAB. I mean... That's the point of using SDKs and APIs... To not have to talk with the CPU yourself.
Cool idea. One problem though: the suffering when you finish a craft and can't fly it right away
